Sullivan | Against UK, leads don't last

Tim Sullivan, tsullivan@courier-journal.com 11:36 p.m. EST December 10, 2014

UK's Andrew Harrison gets a steal during the University of Kentucky men's basketball game against Columbia at Rupp Arena in Lexington, Ky. Wednesday, December 10, 2014.(Photo: By Mike Weaver, Special to the CJ)

3 CONNECT 8 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. – It couldn't last. The odds were too long and Columbia's bench was too short. The problem with playing Kentucky is that when your team hits the wall, John Calipari simply hits the reset button.

He sends in a fresh wave of future professionals and uses his depth to exploit your exhaustion. When a college coach can substitute from a menu of McDonald's All-Americans, that's a formula that makes for a lot of happy meals and fosters an air of inevitability at Rupp Arena.

And so it was Wednesday night. The top-ranked Wildcats spotted their Ivy League visitors the game's first 11 points, trailed 25-23 at the half and 34-33 with less than 15 minutes left, but pulled away to a 56-46 victory that felt more like deliverance than domination, so much so that the final buzzer occasioned only muted applause.

Kentucky coach John Calipari talks about his team's slow start and eventual victory over Columbia in Rupp Arena

The Wildcats are 10-0, have won every game by double digits, but are still looking for a consistent identity on the offensive end.

"We can't come into Rupp thinking that we are going to run over teams," UK forward Derek Willis said. "Yes, we're a really good team. It's everyone's Super Bowl when they come in here. It's really tough, (but) we've just got to stay driven."

It's tough to stay driven, though, when your gearshift seems to be stuck in neutral. Calipari thought Wednesday's showing was at least partially attributable to his team's lack of drive – "I thought the energy was so bad," he complained afterward – as well as its continued shooting woes.

"Without energy," Calipari said, "we're not the best team in the country. Not even close."

MORE: UK survives tough test against Columbia

That the Wildcats keep winning in spite of their failings is, at this point, a tribute to the strength of numbers rather than high purpose; to attrition rather than marksmanship.

"We didn't quite execute on keeping them off the glass, which is everyone's No. 1 priority when they come in here" Columbia coach Kyle Smith said. "Trying to fend off the waves of guys coming at you, it just kind of wore us down."

    For nearly 27 minutes, the Lions were at least equal to the task. Despite Kentucky's daunting size, they attacked the basket without apparent trepidation, and they made enough of their 3-point shots to establish both a healthy lead and a level of comfort with their surroundings.

    At various points in the proceedings, Smith might have taken a page from the Lee Corso playbook and called a timeout to take a team photograph with the scoreboard showing Columbia leading the nation's newly unanimous No. 1 team. But having played then-No. 2 Michigan State within nine points last season, the Lions have moved past "pinch-me" moments and moral victories to a place where they believe in their own possibilities.

    "I think we started off believing that we could win in the locker room, yesterday and the day before," Columbia senior center Cory Osetkowski said. "We have to come into a game like this believing we can win, and that was our mindset through the whole game. Even if we get down, we always believe we can come back, hit a shot here and there, get a stop. That's what basketball is."

    MORE: Game Rewind | UK survives Columbia's scare

    If Kentucky believed an upset was possible, though, its play did not convey an appropriate sense of urgency. Starting forward Alex Poythress earned a quick benching when Calipari judged him too passive. This enabled Trey Lyles to play a season-high 30 minutes, collect a season-high 10 rebounds and appear for post-game interviews to recount Calipari's halftime speech.

    "He was happy that a team was coming in here and punching us in the mouth," Lyles said. "That's what we needed and we came out and responded in the second half."

    Ultimately, it was the little-used Willis who supplied the spark that enabled Kentucky to pull ahead. His two free throws with 13:18 remaining gave the Wildcats their first lead of the game at 36-34. Columbia would later slice the lead to a single point, at 38-37, but a dunk by Aaron Harrison, a layup by Marcus Lee and another dunk by Willie Cauley-Stein served to show how difficult it can be to deny the Wildcats inside.

    In the first half, Kentucky's rebounding edge was just 17-15. In the second, it was 24-13.

    "They fought us in the post," Calipari said. "And they fought more than our guys fought."

    It couldn't last. And it didn't.

    Tim Sullivan can be reached at (502) 582-4650, by email at tsullivan@courier-journal.com, and on Twitter @TimSullivan714
